key_points: Colin Powell, the first black U.S. Secretary of State, died at 84 due to COVID-19 complications.
Despite being fully vaccinated, Powell had a compromised immune system from multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer.
He served as national security adviser, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and oversaw the US invasions of Panama and Kuwait.
Powell's legacy was tarnished by his 2003 speech to the United Nations, falsely asserting Iraq had weapons of mass destruction.
He resigned in 2005, later calling the speech a 'blot' on his record.
President George W. Bush and President Joe Biden led tributes, highlighting Powell's service and leadership.
Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken paid personal tributes to Powell.
Powell's career included key roles during and after the Cold War, including negotiating treaties with the Soviet Union.
After his government service, he endorsed Democratic presidential candidates, leading to criticism from Republican figures.
Powell is survived by his wife, Alma Powell, and their three children.
